awd_titl_txt: CRII: III: Novel Computational Social Choice Extensions for Highly Distributed Decision-Making Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the last two decades, there has been a growing interest in the aggregation of individual preferences into socially desirable collective choices (e.g., crowdsourced recommendations, online voting), helping to propel the new interdisciplinary field of computational social choice. In many ways, the emphasis on examining whether and how preference aggregation algorithms can be designed to ensure fairness, avoid strategic manipulation, and achieve other socially desirable properties is driven by the largely unchecked prevalence of automated "black-box" decision-making technologies within everyday life. While the rising interest in this new field has resulted in various landmark results, implementation of the more socially beneficial methodologies within modern contexts remains severely limited due to a combination of incompatible assumptions and computational difficulties. This research project will seek to extend the real-world applicability of these robust methodologies by melding socio-theoretical insights, efficient algorithms, and advanced operations research techniques. Accordingly, this novel approach will build interdisciplinary bridges with computer science and expose computational social choice to new audiences. Moreover, through an overarching emphasis on rigorous theoretical underpinnings, the envisioned contributions will address the pressing need to develop and implement interpretable decision-making algorithms. Hence, the outcomes of this project will prospectively have widespread impacts on society. 

 The advances envisioned through the completion of this project will expand the traditional scope of computational social choice, particularly of Kemeny aggregation, which is widely regarded as one of the most robust preference-ranking aggregation frameworks in the literature. The focus of this research project will be on highly distributed decision-making contexts, which are often characterized by large numbers of alternatives, tied (i.e., partial) preferences, errors, and/or incompleteness. This will be accomplished by exploring symbiotic relationships between social choice theory, efficient algorithms, and operations research techniques. Planned research tasks will include: (i) Establishing social choice axioms and properties that different distance measures should satisfy when dealing with partial and incomplete preference rankings; (ii) Constructing mathematical models and decomposition algorithms that take advantage of these insights; and (iii) Exploring the validity and pragmatic implications of these measures via formal statistical methods and benchmark instances of preference data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is motivated by a burgeoning interest across many applications in the aggregation of individual preferences (i.e., subjective comparisons over a set of alternatives) into socially desirable collective judgments, which has helped to revitalize the field of social choice over the last two decades. This renewed interest emanates in large part from landmark results on the varying quality of socially desirable outcomes that can or cannot be achieved by different types of voting systems. Such formal guarantees stand in stark contrast with the susceptibility to spurious patterns and the lack of interpretability exhibited by "black box" decision-making technologies, which are prevalent in nearly all facets of everyday life. Yet, the implementation of the more principled preference aggregation methodologies within modern contexts remains severely limited due to a combination of incompatible assumptions and computational challenges.

The primary focus of this research project is on a voting system known as Kemeny aggregation, which is synonymous with robust preference-ranking aggregation, owing to its intuitive geometric underpinnings and to the set of social choice properties its outcomes have been shown to guarantee. Due to its inherent computational difficulties and vast solution space, Kemeny aggregation has been applied mostly in inexact forms, meaning through algorithms that can reproduce some but not all its principled characteristics. Exact implementations of this framework have been limited to relatively small problem instances with up to tens of alternatives. Additionally, most exact and inexact implementations are not equipped to handle ties or incompleteness, which are common characteristics of preference data in modern highly distributed decision-making contexts.

Overall, the intellectual merits of this NSF CRII award reside in significant strides toward advancing the real-world applicability of social choice and ranking aggregation methodologies. The project produced many novel computational techniques for enhancing the implementation of Kemeny aggregation on real-world applications. These contributions include the derivation of several mathematical programming models that have enabled the exact implementation of this principled framework and variations thereof on instances with up to 300 alternatives and which may contain ties and high levels of incompleteness. They also include novel problem decomposition techniques, which expedited exact implementation on certain instances with nearly 1,000 alternatives. Furthermore, the project derived approximation algorithms that solved benchmark problem instances with and without ties and with nearly 3,000 of alternatives within 2 minutes, while ensuring instance-specific guarantees regarding the proximity to optimality of the returned solution. These models and algorithms were shown to significantly outperform their respective exact and inexact counterparts.

The intellectual merits of this award also involve numerous theoretical findings, the most important of which is the insight that the social choice properties that are satisfied by Kemeny aggregation can be leveraged to expedite the exact implementation of this voting system. Such insights were used to establish the formal guarantees of the above-mentioned decomposition techniques and approximation algorithms. The project also introduced new voting properties to apply this guiding insight to problem instances with ties. Additional theoretical contributions include a study of a fundamental mathematical structure known as the weak order polytope, which is interrelated with the set of feasible solutions of the Kemeny aggregation problem with and without ties. It also includes the introduction of a generalized framework for the treatment of ties in ranking aggregation and other specialized models (i.e., top-k aggregation).

The broader impacts of this award reside primarily in the building of interdisciplinary bridges, exposure of principled methodologies for decision-making to new audiences, and development of young scholars. The project disseminated its results widely, including through seven journal papers, six conference papers, and numerous presentations at conferences related to Operations Research, Computer Science, and Human Computation. These results were the subject of two PhD dissertations, and they afforded additional opportunities to graduate student researchers. Notably, a female PhD student supported through this award secured a postdoc position at a leading research university upon graduation, and she is now an assistant professor in a Hispanic Serving Institution. As part of this award, a new course on Computational Social Choice was developed and delivered to students from multiple academic departments. The REU portion of the project engaged undergraduate students, including in over 10 multidisciplinary research internships during the academic year and summer. Their participation led to a number of academic publications and to two Computer Science honors theses. Some of the former participants have since entered graduate school.
